title: 107_s1074
content: The "FBI Reform Commission Act of 2001" is created to establish the FBI Review Commission. The FBI Review Commission is established to conduct an independent examination of the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), focusing on systemic aspects, its relationship with other law enforcement entities, and recommendations for improvement. The Commission will consist of 12 members appointed by the Majority. The FBI Review Commission will consist of 12 members appointed by various leaders, including the Majority and Minority Leaders of the Senate and House of Representatives, as well as the President. Members must have expertise in law enforcement, integrity, impartiality, and good judgment. The FBI Review Commission consists of 12 members appointed by Senate and House leaders and the President. Members must have expertise in law enforcement, integrity, and impartiality. The Commission aims for fair representation of various viewpoints and appoints members for the duration of its existence. Vacancies are filled promptly to maintain the Commission's functionality. The FBI Review Commission consists of 12 members appointed by Senate and House leaders and the President. Members must have expertise in law enforcement, integrity, and impartiality. Vacancies are promptly filled to maintain functionality. The Commission meets at the call of the Chair, holds its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed, and a majority constitutes a quorum for meetings. The Commission's duties include studying the FBI's methods for storing and maintaining information. The FBI Review Commission examines the FBI's procedures for securing and managing information, training and monitoring personnel, and ensuring compliance with laws and regulations. This includes methods for securing information, efficacy of information systems, classification and declassification practices, training methods, accountability for wrongdoing, and treatment of FBI agents. The FBI Review Commission evaluates various aspects of the FBI's operations, including handling of information, training of personnel, use of deadly force, investigation procedures, resource allocation, interactions with other law enforcement agencies, oversight mechanisms, and potential changes to current practices. The FBI Review Commission will study the advisability of altering the FBI's structure and organization, develop recommendations for Congress and the FBI based on their findings, and provide advice, assistance, and testimony as needed. The FBI Review Commission will solicit advice from experts in information security, business management, law enforcement, intelligence, and other relevant areas. The Commission will submit a final report to Congress, the FBI, and the Attorney General within 9 months of all members being appointed. The FBI Review Commission will submit a final report to Congress, the FBI, and the Attorney General containing detailed findings, recommendations, and any dissenting opinions. The FBI Review Commission may submit an interim report before the final report to Congress, the FBI, the Attorney General, and other relevant individuals or organizations. The FBI Review Commission's reports must be accessible to the public and government officials without compromising national security, individual safety, or ongoing investigations. Portions of the reports may be designated as confidential for national security reasons. The FBI Review Commission may hold hearings, take testimony, administer oaths, and establish rules and procedures to carry out its duties under this Act. The FBI Review Commission holds open hearings for the public but may close them for national security, individual safety, or ongoing investigation integrity. Members and agents can take authorized actions, and the Commission can obtain necessary information from federal agencies. The Commission can request information from federal agencies as needed, except when it poses a threat to national security, individual safety, or ongoing investigations. Commission members are compensated at a rate equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule for each day of duty. The Commission members are allowed travel expenses and administrative support services for their duties. They can also hire staff without following certain provisions of the United States Code. The Commission can appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following certain provisions of the United States Code regarding appointments and compensation. The executive director's employment is subject to confirmation by the Commission, and their compensation can be determined by the Commission without limitations on pay rates. The executive director and other personnel appointed by the Commission cannot exceed the pay rate for level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, and the Commission can procure temporary services at rates not exceeding the pay prescribed for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission will terminate 30 days after its establishment. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the final report. Authorization of appropriations is provided for necessary funds without fiscal year limitation.
